content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" is cited as the Act. It excludes space-related income from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalty amounts related to space activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes certain space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and specific interest, rent, or royalty amounts related to space activities. Additionally, there are exceptions for telecommunications services from earth orbit, services provided by weather or earth observation satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Wages received by employees of an employer are also exempt from this provision. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal excises, imposts, duties, and tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by U.S. persons. The exclusion amount under this act will be gradually reduced after December 31, 2012. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products made in outer space from federal taxes, starting from a U.S. facility. The exclusion amount will decrease after December 31, 2012. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from federal taxes and provides a credit for the purchase of qualified space company stock. Effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2003. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" offers a space company investment credit for purchasing qualified stock in a qualified space company. A qualified space company is a domestic C corporation with annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000, and at least 70% of gross receipts are from space-based business. Space-based business is defined as income related to space activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" provides a tax credit for investing in qualified stock of a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company. Qualified stock must be acquired directly at its original issue in exchange for money or services, and the corporation must meet certain criteria to qualify as a space company. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" offers a tax credit for investing in qualified stock of a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company. To qualify, the stock must be acquired directly at its original issue in exchange for money or services. The corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) and be a C corporation. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply if the corporation purchases its own stock. If the issuer of the qualified stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, there is a recapture provision that increases the tax for that year. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" provides a tax credit for investing in qualified stock of a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company. If the issuer of the stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, there is a recapture provision that increases the tax for that year. The credit is allowed as part of the general business credit under section 38(b) of the tax code. The tax code amendments restrict the carryback of the space company investment credit before January 1, 2004. This includes the addition of the space company investment credit to section 196 of the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to costs incurred after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a new section is added for the exclusion of gains from the sale of stock of qualified space corporations. The exclusion of gains from the sale of stock of qualified space corporations applies to domestic C corporations organized for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90% of expenses related to this activity. The exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
